Issues.Title: Prototype shared CsWin32 with System.Drawing.Common
Issues.Body:
This is a rough prototype of a shared interop with System.Drawing.Common. It introduces a new base assembly for shared CsWin32 and other low-level support code.

Converted HGLOBAL, DEVMODE and related stuff to the new shared pattern. Also used the CsWin32 generated GdiplusStartup.

I have almost no idea if packaging is correct here. Assuming it isn't.

`crefs` don't work right when there is overlap in internals. #10524 tracks this, and this change disables the relevant warnings.

I've only smoke tested this with the WinFormsControlsTest.


###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/10525)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Prototype shared CsWin32 with System.Drawing.Common" (#10525)

Issues.Title: XML comment crefs unusable with shared/duplicate CsWin32
Issues.Body:
XML comment `cref`s don't resolve the same way code does. They have visibility to everything, which prevents us from using them when we have duplicate type names in dependent assemblies or types that cross assemblies. We either have to turn off [CS1574](https://learn.microsoft.com/dotnet/csharp/misc/cs1574) and [CS1580](https://learn.microsoft.com/dotnet/csharp/misc/cs1574), or remove lots of existing `cref`s.

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/10320#issuecomment-1858617614
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "XML comment crefs unusable with shared/duplicate CsWin32" (#10524)

Issues.Title: fix ToolStripItem SelectedChanged event is invoked twice
Issues.Body:
After PR [10321 add ToolStripItem.SelectedChanged event](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/10321), tester raised a question: whether it is reasonable to fire SelectedChanged event **twice** when selection status turns from unselected to selected **and** from selected to unselected. After discussion we reached an agreement: the newly added API(ToolStripItem.SelectedChanged) should be consistent with framework's , i.e. when selection status turns from unselected to selected we will fire ToolStripItem.SelectedChanged event. but when selection status turns from selected to unselected we will **not**.

See the discussion [here](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/8548#issuecomment-1862431770)

Issues.Title: Use Cswin32 UIA_X_ID Enums
Issues.Body:
Previously metadata had incorrectly defined UIA_X_ID enums as uints (https://github.com/microsoft/win32metadata/issues/1723). This has now been fixed and is included in current cswin32 version so removing our definition of UIA_X_ID enums in favor of cswin32. 
Verified with Narrator + Accessibility Insights that behavior is expected.

Issues.Title: [Accessibility] CheckBox control should support ValuePattern property
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.Net 9.0 SDK with 9.0.100-alpha.1.23620.7 build

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No

### Issue description

CheckBox control doesn't support ValuePattern property, compared with the CheckedListBox item, which is supported.

**CheckBox:**
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/26474449/764fc5d4-7ce3-4048-b670-951dd565651b)


**CheckedListBox item:**
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/26474449/3a30b49b-71a7-411e-b188-8d70801f392c)


### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a Winforms .Net application
2. Add a checkBox and a checkedListBox control with some items added
3. Build and run application
4. Use Accessibility Insight tool to observe the ValuePattern property for checkBox and one item of checkedListBox
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Accessibility] CheckBox control should support ValuePattern property" (#10516)

No, It also repro on .NET 8.0.

### Issue description

VS stop running while opening message box with Options's value to DefaultDesktopOnly/ServiceNotification


## Repro steps:
1. Git clone  https://github.com/dotnet/winforms
2. Open CMD from clone folder and run "start-vs.cmd" command open project
3. Select WinformsControlTest app, right click it to set as startup project
4. Build and run, click "MessageBox button
5. Set Options's value to DefaultDesktopOnly/ServiceNotification, Click Show MessageBox

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/130345015/51b017d2-8540-4e53-90ad-bb4050f695a5


## Actual result: 
VS stop running

## Expected  result: 
Message box will be opened without error

Issues.Title: WinForms Designer fails to load Form in Visual Studio 2022 (Could not load file or assembly 'Microsoft.Bcl.AsyncInterfaces, Version=7.0.0.0)
Issues.Body:
### Environment

Visual Studio Version 17.8.3

### .NET version

.NET 5

### Did this work in a previous version of Visual Studio and/or previous .NET release?

Yes, the same form does open without issue in Visual Studio 2019.
And I believe it also worked in an older update of Visual Studio 2022. But I can't test that to be sure, since I can't install older Visual Studio 2022 versions?

### Issue description

In a .NET 5 project that has a (transitive) reference to nuget package System.Text.Json 7.0.2, opening the designer of a form fails to load the form. The "Loading designer..." message is never replaced with the actual Form.

PS: I am aware that System.Text.Json 7.0.2 is not guaranteed to work .NET 5, but this did actually work correctly up until (assuming) a change in the WinForms designer/Visual Studio.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a .NET 5 windows forms project
2. Notice the default Form opens correctly
3. Install Nuget package System.Text.Json 7.0.2 in this project
4. Notice the default Form does NOT open anymore

Issues.Title: Release Pointer when Index Setting ComSafeArrayScope
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

Fixes https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/10443

If the object being placed into a SafeArray is a IDispatch or IUnknown, SafeArray does an `AddRef` on the object (https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/oleauto/nf-oleauto-safearrayputelement#remarks). This means to maintain the correct ref count, we should be releasing the object that we put into the SafeArray. This was missed in `ComSafeArrayScope.CreateFromInterfaceArray`

Before:
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/30007367/1bcccb0d-ca2e-441e-86e8-52a531a23dc4)

After: No AccessibleObject leaks
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/30007367/c7ede670-e738-41ba-8de2-de04dbc67d78)

Note:
This should also fix other AccessibleObject memory leaks that have been noted as .NET 9 regressions.

Issues.Title: [release/8.0.x] Fix expandable property grid entries
Issues.Body:
Fixes #https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/10427
Port of a .NET9 fix - https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/10433

## Proposed changes
Fixed a typo where we were not referencing the right local variable.

## Customer Impact
DevExpress can't use expandable property grid entries, i.e. entries where a child value is displayed on the parent line.

## Regression? 

- Yes 

## Risk

-low, this is a very specific scenario

## Test methodology 
Manual and unit test.

Issues.Title: Numeric/DomainUpDown and its elements accessible objects are leaking in memory
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET 9.0.100-alpha.1.23614.10 + private dlls(build from main branch of WinForms repo)

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Not tested/verified

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Repro on the latest .NET 8.0 (.NET 8.0.200-preview.23617.2), previously fixed on .NET 8.0(.NET 8.0.100-alpha.1.22451.15).

Original issue: [#7328](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/7328).

### Issue description

UpDown items accessible objects are left in memory after the Numeric/DomainUpDown control instance with its items was inspected with accessibility tool (like Accessibility Insights or Inspect) and the form with Numeric/DomainUpDown  is closed, garbage is collected, but accessibility tool is still opened.

Report from WinDbg:
![9 0numericupdpwn](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/94418985/8d23f7ab-2d9e-4616-a699-6de2cf169038)


### Steps to reproduce

Tested sample application: [NumericUpDown.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/13700744/NumericUpDown.zip)
Or [DomainUpDown.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/13700746/DomainUpDown.zip)

1.Create a parent form with two buttons: one will be opening a child form with the Numeric/DomainUpDown control and the other will collect the garbage.
2. Start project without debugging(Ctrl+F5).
3. Attaching project to WinDbg and adding symbols folder.
4. Start the Accessibility Insights tool.
5. Press the second button to open the child form with Numeric/DomainUpDown.
6. Automatic checks for the Numeric/DomainUpDown control using Accessibility Insight.
7. Close the child form.
8. Clear memory with the first button of the parent form.
9. Don't close the Accessibility Insights tool.
10. Look for UpDown accessible objects left in memory (using WinDbg).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Numeric/DomainUpDown and its elements accessible objects are leaking in memory" (#10496)
